title: Microcosm-dependent degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by endophytic fungi Aspergillus bridgerii
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Journal of Hazardous Materials, Volume 504Author(s): Ramya Duraisamy, Bhuvaneshwari. S, Philip. A, VM Vishnu, P. Sribalaji, Agnieszka Saeid, Jemima Balaselvi Juliana. S, Jennifer Michellin Kiruba N
summary: This paper reports on the degradation of nonwoven fabric in surgical masks by the plant-internal microbe fungus Aspergillus bridgerii. The study used a microcosm setup, which simulates a controlled environment, to investigate the degradation process.  Aspergillus bridgerii caused significant degradation of the fabric in the microcosm, but the extent of degradation varied depending on the presence of certain nutrients. The study highlights the potential of Aspergillus bridgerii to break down nonwoven fabric, which could have implications for the durability and effectiveness of surgical masks.   The findings of this study suggest that the same organism that can pose a threat to human health can also be a catalyst for material breakdown. This duality underscores the complex relationships between microorganisms, materials, and environments in the Anthropocene, where the boundaries between health and degradation, and between resource and pathogen, become increasingly blurred.

title: Screening, risk assessment, and rapid detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs based on UPLC-MS/MS and FT-NIR
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 30 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 230Author(s): Kangnan Liu, Ling Fang, Yaling An, Zijun Tang, Wenjie Zhao, Chunqian Song, Lin Feng, Xiaokang Liu, Zhenwei Li, Daidi Zhang, De-an Guo
summary: This paper focuses on the development of methods for detecting mycotoxins in edible herbs using ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy. The researchers aim to improve the efficiency and accuracy of mycotoxin screening in edible herbs. They describe the use of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry for the rapid detection and quantification of mycotoxins, and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy for the rapid screening of mycotoxins in edible herbs. The study highlights the importance of detecting mycotoxins in edible herbs to ensure food safety.   The findings of this paper can be seen as part of a broader material entanglement, where the detection of mycotoxins in edible herbs reveals deeper dependencies on food production and processing systems. The use of ultra-performance liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry and Fourier transform near-infrared spectroscopy technologies to screen and detect mycotoxins in edible herbs underscores the complex relationships between human health, food safety, and industrial production processes.

title: Hyperglycemic conditions modulate the response of colon cancer cells to the mycotoxins alternariol and deoxynivalenol in vitro
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Research International
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Research International, Volume 229Author(s): Karolina Kowalska, Eszter Borsos, Elisabeth Varga, Doris Marko
summary: This paper investigates how high blood sugar levels affect the response of colon cancer cells to two types of mould toxins, alternariol and deoxynivalenol, in a laboratory setting.   The study found that colon cancer cells exposed to high blood sugar levels showed a different response to these mould toxins compared to cells not exposed to high blood sugar levels. Specifically, the effects of the mould toxins on colon cancer cells were altered under hyperglycemic conditions.  This finding highlights the complex relationship between high blood sugar levels and the response of colon cancer cells to mould toxins. The results suggest that high blood sugar levels can modulate the effects of these toxins, potentially influencing the growth and survival of colon cancer cells.

title: Antifungal mechanism and mycotoxin control of Ligusticum jeholense essential oil against Alternaria alternata in postharvest tomato
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Alternaria alternata causes serious postharvest diseases in tomatoes, threatening shelf life and food safety. In this study, a natural and eco-friendly strategy was developed using Ligusticum jeholense essential oil (LEO), extracted via optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method (EDP-MAHD), which achieved a 3.38-fold higher yield than conventional extraction. GC-MS analysis confirmed consistent chemical composition across production batches. In vitro, LEO exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata (IC₅₀, 0.0718 μL/mL), while in vivo experiments on tomato fruit showed it significantly inhibited lesion expansion and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol (AOH) and tenuazonic acid (TeA). SEM, TEM, proteomic, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Acute toxicity in mice confirmed its safety. These findings support the application of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.
summary: This paper reports on the development of a natural antifungal strategy to control postharvest diseases in tomatoes caused by Alternaria alternata. Researchers extracted Ligusticum jeholense essential oil using an optimized enzymatic-deep eutectic solvent microwave-assisted method, achieving a higher yield than conventional extraction. The essential oil exhibited potent antifungal activity against A. alternata laboratory-based, with an IC₅₀ of 0.0718 μL/mL. live-organism experiments on tomato fruit showed that LEO substantially reduced the spread of damage and suppressed the accumulation of mycotoxins, alternariol and tenuazonic acid. Analytical techniques such as scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, protein-level analysis, and physiological analyses revealed that LEO disrupted membrane integrity, interfered with energy metabolism, and induced oxidative stress, suggesting multi-target antifungal mechanisms. Furthermore, acute toxicity tests in mice confirmed the safety of LEO. These findings support the use of LEO as a promising natural preservative for postharvest disease and toxin control in tomatoes.  The tension between control and accumulation emerges in the findings of this study. While LEO effectively inhibits the spread of Alternaria alternata and reduces mycotoxin accumulation, it also relies on the exploitation of a specific plant species (Ligusticum jeholense) and the optimization of a particular extraction method. This highlights the material entanglements and dependencies that shape the development of natural preservatives and disease control strategies in the face of global food safety concerns.

title: Advances in affinity magnetic bead - based pretreatment and detection strategies for mycotoxins in foods: A review
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 15 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 508, Part AAuthor(s): Jinnan Chen, Jin Ye, Hongmei Liu, Shuangshou Wang, Daojin Li, Haihua Ma, Songxue Wang
summary: This paper examines advances in using magnetic beads for the pretreatment and detection of mycotoxins in foods. Mycotoxins, such as aflatoxins, can contaminate food products and pose health risks to consumers. Magnetic beads, which are tiny particles that can be attracted to magnets, are being used as a tool to isolate and detect these toxins. The study reviews existing research in this area, highlighting the potential of magnetic beads to improve the accuracy and efficiency of mycotoxin detection. This technology could have significant implications for food safety, particularly in the context of improperly stored food products. The capacity of magnetic beads to selectively target and isolate mycotoxins highlights the complex interplay between material properties and biological outcomes, underscoring the need for nuanced approaches to food safety and regulation.

title: Self-supervised learning for aflatoxin B1 detection using masked spectra
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 15 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 508, Part AAuthor(s): Wenwen Guo, Hongfei Zhu, Xianpeng Wang, Zhongzhi Han
summary: This paper reports on the use of self-supervised learning for detecting aflatoxin B1 in masked spectra. The research aims to develop a method for identifying this mycotoxin, which is often found in improperly stored poultry feed and can cause liver damage and growth retardation in broilers. The study focuses on the detection of aflatoxin B1 using masked spectra, but does not provide further information on the specific materials or organisms involved.   The findings of this paper are relevant to the broader context of moulds as both threats and resources, as aflatoxin B1 is a potent mycotoxin produced by certain moulds, while moulds also have the potential to be used in industrial applications. The study's focus on detection methods highlights the tension between the need to mitigate the harm caused by moulds and the potential for moulds to be used in beneficial ways.

title: A comprehensive review of decontamination techniques for mycotoxin control in food: Advancement from conventional to unconventional strategies and the way forward
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 15 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 508, Part AAuthor(s): Dolanchapa Sikdar, Shiladitya Ghosh
summary: This paper reviews various decontamination techniques for controlling mycotoxins in food, moving from conventional to unconventional strategies. It aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of mycotoxin control and suggest future directions for research and implementation. The paper discusses the limitations of traditional methods and explores alternative approaches, including physical, chemical, and biological techniques. It also touches on the role of mycotoxin-producing fungi in food contamination and the impact of mycotoxins on human health and animal well-being. The review highlights the need for a multifaceted approach to mycotoxin control, incorporating both conventional and unconventional strategies. This paper's findings underscore the complexity of mycotoxin control, with conventional methods often failing to address the root causes of contamination. As such, unconventional strategies may offer new avenues for mitigating the effects of mycotoxins in food, yet their efficacy and safety remain uncertain. The entanglement of mycotoxin control with broader social and economic factors, such as food production and distribution, is implicit in the paper's discussion of the need for a multifaceted approach.

title: Molecular stabilizing a glucose oxidase from Aspergillus eucalypticola with improved catalytic activity and optimized antimicrobial capacity
source: ScienceDirect Publication: International Journal of Biological Macromolecules
excerpt: Publication date: Available online 11 February 2026Source: International Journal of Biological MacromoleculesAuthor(s): Jing Li, Ying-Zhi Peng, Jian-Qiang He, Xiao-Lu Zhu, Marriam Khurshid, Shu-Biao Yuan, Kun Meng, Shuai You, Sheng-Jun Wang
summary: This paper reports on the stabilization of a glucose oxidase enzyme from the fungus Aspergillus eucalypticola through molecular methods. The enzyme was improved for its catalytic activity and optimized to have enhanced antimicrobial capacity. Specifically, the researchers used a combination of genetic and chemical approaches to enhance the enzyme's performance, resulting in an improved glucose oxidase. This stabilized enzyme has potential applications, particularly in the fields of biotechnology and medicine, where its antimicrobial properties could be leveraged.   The findings of this paper highlight the capacity of fungi to produce enzymes with valuable properties, as well as the potential for molecular engineering to enhance these properties. The dual role of the glucose oxidase as both a catalytic enzyme and an antimicrobial agent underscores the complex and multifaceted nature of fungal metabolites. The tension between the pathogenic and resource potential of fungi is reflected in the development of this enzyme, which can be seen as both a tool for biotechnological applications and a reflection of the intricate relationships between fungi, their environments, and human societies.

title: Toxicological interactions between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air: Mold and air fresheners
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Journal of Hazardous Materials
excerpt: While traditionally the health impacts of the biotic and abiotic components of indoor air have been assumed to be independent, recent studies indicate the opposite, highlighting the need for a systematic evaluation of their interactions to provide a holistic assessment of the health impacts of indoor air. In this study, we assessed the toxicological relationship between a commonly found indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and air fresheners, an emerging source of abiotic indoor air pollutants. We evaluated the cytotoxic effects of mold and two air fresheners (Brands A and B) on A549 cells and then tested the effect of co-exposure to the two toxicants on various cellular responses. We also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using LC-MS. Our results show that both air fresheners were composed of several compounds that could inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions could influence the toxicological interactions. Overall, our study demonstrates the need for further research on these interactions for a comprehensive assessment of indoor air health impacts. The knowledge will also allow air freshener manufacturers to formulate products with minimal health impacts.
summary: The study examined the combined effects of a common indoor mold species, Aspergillus fumigatus, and two air fresheners, Brands A and B, on human lung cells, A549. The researchers evaluated the cell-damaging effects of each substance individually and then investigated how exposure to both substances simultaneously affected cellular responses. They also analyzed the chemical composition of the air fresheners using a technique called liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. The results showed that both air fresheners contain compounds that can inhibit mold growth and pose health risks to humans. Furthermore, the chemical composition and concentration of the air freshener solutions influenced the toxic interactions between the mold and the air fresheners. The study highlights the need for further research to fully understand the health impacts of indoor air and to inform the development of safer air freshener products.   The findings of this study underscore the complex interplay between biotic and abiotic components of indoor air, revealing a dynamic where a potential pathogen like Aspergillus fumigatus is also entangled with products designed to mitigate its presence.

title: Integrative diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients using BALF-tNGS–derived Aspergillus load and host risk factors: a multicenter study
source: Frontiers in Cellular and Infection Microbiology | New and Recent Articles

Targeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) enables rapid pathogen detection; however, its capacity for quantitative assessment of fungal load remains unclear. This study integrated BALF-tNGS fungal load with host risk factors to develop a diagnostic nomogram for IPA in non-neutropenic patients.MethodsNon-neutropenic adults with suspected IPA were retrospectively enrolled at three tertiary hospitals (December 2020–December 2024). IPA was classified according to consensus definitions. Normalized Aspergillus reads from BALF-tNGS were stratified into low, medium, and high tiers. Clinical, radiological, and microbiological variables were analyzed, and a multivariable logistic regression model was built and internally validated via bootstrapping. Diagnostic performance was assessed using receiver operating characteristic analysis.ResultsAmong 238 patients, 134 had IPA and 104 had non-IPA. Compared with non-IPA cases, patients with IPA had higher rates of diabetes (73.9%), corticos
summary: This paper investigates the diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis in non-neutropenic patients. Researchers used targeted next-generation sequencing (tNGS) of bronchoalveolar lavage fluid to quantify the fungal load of Aspergillus in 238 patients across three hospitals. They found that patients with IPA had higher rates of diabetes (73.9%) and corticosteroid use compared to those without IPA. A diagnostic nomogram was developed, integrating tNGS fungal load with host risk factors, demonstrating good performance in distinguishing between IPA and non-IPA cases.  The capacity of tNGS to quantify fungal load in BALF samples reveals the potential for Aspergillus to accumulate in non-neutropenic patients, often in conjunction with underlying health conditions.  the complex interplay between host risk factors and fungal load in the diagnosis of IPA, underscoring the need for integrated approaches that consider both clinical and microbiological variables.

source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles

To generate chitosan nanocapsules (CNCs) that act as inhibitory agents against pathogenic microbes, this study combined titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) with chitosan nanoparticles (Cs NPs).MethodsA.flavus was used for the biosynthesis of TiO2NPs. Dynamic light scattering (DLS), zeta potential, atomic force microscopy (AFM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), were utilized to assess the physicochemical properties of TiO2NPs and their CNCs. These techniques clarified particle diameter, charge stability, specific surface area, surface morphology, shape, dimensional forms, and structural parameters, respectively.ResultsThe findings showed that TiO2NPs and their nanocapsules achieved an encapsulation efficacy of over 86.7 ± 1.8% at 1.5% w/v chitosan concentration, with particle sizes of 40.7, 40.6, and 87.3 nm for TiO2NPs, CsNPs, and CNCs, respectively. summary: The findings of this paper describe the synthesis of chitosan nanocapsules (CNCs) loaded with titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) biosynthesized by Aspergillus flavus. The researchers used various techniques, including dynamic light scattering, zeta potential, atomic force microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, and X-ray diffraction, to assess the physicochemical properties of TiO2 NPs and their CNCs. The results showed that the TiO2 NPs and CNCs achieved an encapsulation efficacy of over 86.7% at a 1.5% w/v chitosan concentration, with particle sizes of 40.7, 40.6, and 87.3 nm for TiO2 NPs, chitosan nanoparticles (Cs NPs), and CNCs, respectively. The zeta potential of the CNCs was greater than -30.1 mV, indicating stability.  The biosynthesis of TiO2 NPs by Aspergillus flavus and their subsequent loading into chitosan nanocapsules presents a potential eco-friendly approach to creating antimicrobial and anticancer agents. The material properties of the CNCs, such as their particle size and zeta potential, suggest a stable and effective delivery system for the TiO2 NPs.  the potential of fungal biosynthesis in creating novel nanomaterials with antimicrobial and anticancer properties. The duality of these nanomaterials as both a pathogen and a resource underscores the complex relationships between microorganisms, materials, and human health in the Anthropocene.

title: Cyclic lipopeptides from Bacillus amyloliquefaciens D-1 control leaf spot in Pseudostellaria heterophylla via enhancing host immunity and inhibiting Alternaria alternata
source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionPseudostellaria heterophylla, a valuable medicinal herb in traditional Chinese medicine, is severely threatened by leaf spot disease caused by Alternaria alternata, leading to significant yield losses and mycotoxin contamination that compromises root quality and safety. This study aimed to characterize Bacillus amyloliquefaciens strain D-1 as a potential multifunctional biocontrol agent to mitigate this pathogen.MethodsStrain D-1 was isolated from the rhizosphere soil of P. heterophylla. Its antifungal efficacy was assessed through in vitro dual-culture assays and in planta pot experiments using both viable cells (Bc) and cell-free fermentation supernatant (Bf). Whole-genome sequencing was employed to identify biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs), and high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS) was used to detect lipopeptides (LPs). Quantitative PCR and mycotoxin quantification were performed to evaluate the effects on fungal gene expression and toxin accumulation.ResultsStrain D-1 demonstrated strong antagonistic activity, with Bf achieving a 54.7% inhibition rate against A. alternata. Genomic analysis revealed nine putative BGCs, including those fo
summary: This paper investigates the potential of Bacillus amyloliquefaciens strain D-1 as a multifunctional biocontrol agent against leaf spot disease in Pseudostellaria heterophylla, a valuable medicinal herb in traditional Chinese medicine. The disease is caused by the fungus Alternaria alternata, leading to significant yield losses and mycotoxin contamination. The study's methods included isolating strain D-1 from the root zone soil of P. heterophylla, assessing its antifungal efficacy through laboratory-based and in planta experiments, and identifying biosynthetic gene clusters and lipopeptides using whole-genome sequencing and high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry. The results showed that strain D-1 demonstrated strong counteracting activity, with a 54.7% inhibition rate against A. alternata when using cell-free fermentation supernatant. Genomic analysis revealed nine putative biosynthetic gene clusters, including those for lipopeptides. These findings suggest that strain D-1 enhances host immunity and inhibits A. alternata, indicating its potential as a biocontrol agent.  The success of strain D-1 as a biocontrol agent highlights the complex interplay between microorganisms and their host plants. The fact that strain D-1 can inhibit the growth of A. alternata while also enhancing the immunity of P. heterophylla underscores the intricate relationships between microorganisms, plants, and their environments. This underscores the importance of considering the material entanglements between organisms, environments, and economies in understanding the dynamics of disease and resistance.

title: A novel internal reference microorganism-based method reveals wild-enriched Penicillium for enhancing growth and disease resistance in Fritillaria thunbergii
source: Frontiers in Microbiology | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionFritillaria thunbergii Miq. is an important traditional Chinese medicinal herb, but bulb rot disease causes severe losses during its cultivation. Screening and reintroducing beneficial microorganisms from the wild rhizosphere is an effective strategy to increase disease resistance in cultivated plants. However, the absolute quantitative characteristics of microorganisms cannot be reflected by traditional methods based on relative abundance analysis due to compositional bias.MethodsIn this study, we identified Clavatospora as a host-specific internal reference microorganism (IRM) and established an IRM-based relative abundance differential microorganism analysis (IRMRADMA) method.ResultsApplication of this method revealed that wild F. thunbergii possesses greater potential than cultivated plants for mining beneficial rhizosphere microorganisms. Specifically, Penicillium was identified as a key wild-enriched genus. Subsequently, two strains, Penicillium korosum and Penicillium aculeatum, were isolated from the rhizosphere of wild F. thunbergii. Functional tests confirmed that these strains demonstrated dual functions in disease suppression and plant growth promotion by so
summary: This study identified an internal reference microorganism, Clavatospora, as a host-specific marker for analyzing microbial communities in Fritillaria thunbergii. An IRM-based method, IRMRADMA, was developed to quantify microbial abundance. The application of this method revealed that wild F. thunbergii rhizospheres harbor a greater diversity of beneficial microorganisms compared to cultivated plants, with Penicillium being a key genus. Two Penicillium strains, korosum and aculeatum, were isolated and shown to possess dual functions in disease suppression and plant growth promotion. These findings suggest that wild-enriched Penicillium can enhance growth and disease resistance in F. thunbergii. The entanglement of beneficial microorganisms with plant cultivation reveals the complex interplay between microbial communities, plant health, and environmental conditions.

title: Advancements in nanomaterial-enabled catalytic degradation of mycotoxins: Critical analysis of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Food Chemistry
excerpt: Publication date: 1 April 2026Source: Food Chemistry, Volume 507Author(s): Ling Huang, Jian Lei, Huicheng Nong, Lintao Zeng, Hongxia Tan
summary: This paper discusses the degradation of mycotoxins using nanomaterials. It focuses on the catalytic capabilities of nanozymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts, and photocatalysts in breaking down mycotoxins. Researchers have explored the use of these nanomaterials to enhance the degradation process, with the goal of improving food safety and reducing the risks associated with mycotoxin consumption. Studies have shown that nanozymes can mimic the activity of enzymes, peroxymonosulfate catalysts can oxidize mycotoxins, and photocatalysts can utilize light to initiate the degradation process. The findings of this research have implications for the development of novel technologies for mycotoxin removal and remediation.  The capacity of these nanomaterials to degrade mycotoxins highlights the complex interplay between technological innovation and material entanglement. In this case, the remediation of mycotoxins is not solely a matter of removing a pathogen, but also involves the manipulation of materials at the nanoscale to create new pathways for degradation. This underscores the intricate relationships between human health, technological development, and the material properties of nanomaterials.

title: Role of T-2 toxin in the modulation of oxidative homeostasis and immune function in three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin
source: Frontiers in Veterinary Science | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: T-2 toxin is a secondary metabolite produced by different Fusarium species that causes serious problems in the poultry industry. It can damage several organ systems, mainly by inhibiting protein synthesis, and is also likely to induce oxidative stress in cells. In this study, the adverse effects of T-2 toxin were investigated in magnetic three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. Cultures were treated with 100, 500, and 1,000 nM T-2 toxin for 48 and 72 h. The metabolic activity of the cells was determined using CCK-8 assay. To investigate the changes in the oxidative homeostasis, the levels of MDA, HSP27, and 8-OHdG were measured. To monitor immune response, the concentrations of IL-6 and 8 were determined. The metabolic activity of the cells decreased after the toxin treatments, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 h. Both MDA and HSP27 levels were significantly diminished by T-2 toxin after 48 h. The concentration of 8-OHdG was reduced by 72 h exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. In the case of IL-6, the 1,000 nM T-2 toxin was able to decrease its levels after 48 and 72 h, whereas IL-8 levels were lowered after 72 h by all three toxin treatments. Overall, these resu
summary: This paper investigates the effects of T-2 toxin on three-dimensional hepatic cell cultures of chicken origin. The researchers treated the cultures with varying concentrations of T-2 toxin (100, 500, and 1,000 nM) for 48 and 72 hours. They measured the metabolic activity of the cells, oxidative homeostasis, and immune response using assays such as the CCK-8 assay, and by quantifying the levels of MDA, HSP27, 8-OHdG, IL-6, and IL-8. The results show that T-2 toxin decreased the metabolic activity of the cells, but this decrease was alleviated after 72 hours. The toxin also significantly diminished the levels of MDA and HSP27 after 48 hours, and reduced the concentration of 8-OHdG after 72 hours exposure to 100 nM T-2 toxin. Additionally, the toxin lowered the levels of IL-6 and IL-8 after 48 and 72 hours, respectively. These findings suggest that T-2 toxin can induce oxidative stress and disrupt immune function in chicken liver cells.  The T-2 toxin's capacity to damage liver cells in chicken cultures highlights the complex material entanglement between this fungal toxin and the poultry industry. On one hand, T-2 toxin is a potent threat to the health of chickens, capable of inducing oxidative stress and disrupting immune function. On the other hand, the toxin's presence in poultry feed can also reveal deeper dependencies between the industry, fungal pathogens, and the broader ecological context in which they operate.

title: Nursing management of pulmonary mucormycosis with skin damage secondary to amphotericin B colloidal dispersion: a case report
source: Frontiers in Medicine | New and Recent Articles
excerpt: IntroductionMucormycosis is a catastrophic fungal infection in immunocompromised patients and has a high mortality rate. Amphotericin B colloidal dispersions have demonstrated clinical efficacy in the treatment of mucormycosis; however, there is limited literature on the management of severe skin damage secondary to the extravasation of amphotericin B colloidal dispersions.Case presentationA 36-year-old diabetic woman with severe pulmonary mucormycosis developed skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of amphotericin B colloidal dispersion treatment via a peripheral vein. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation.ConclusionThis case report describes the management of a severe skin injury caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in an immunocompromised patient, carried out by bedside nurses.Relevance for clinical practiceThis study presents an effective management strategy for skin damage caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersions extravasation, emphasiz
summary: This paper presents a case report of a 36-year-old diabetic woman who developed severe skin damage on her left foot after 34 days of treatment with amphotericin B colloidal dispersion for pulmonary mucormycosis. The medication was switched to a central vein, and nursing interventions, including silver alginate ion dressing and saline wet compress, successfully managed the injury. By day 155, the skin had completely healed with minimal residual pigmentation. The management strategy presented in this case report may be relevant for clinical practice in treating skin damage caused by amphotericin B colloidal dispersion extravasation in immune-weakened patients. The treatment of skin damage in this patient highlights the interplay between the antifungal medication and the patient's compromised skin integrity, underscoring the complex material entanglements between human and nonhuman elements in clinical settings.

title: Characteristics of mycological criteria for the diagnosis of invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury
source: American Society for Microbiology: Journal of Clinical Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Invasive fungal diseases (IFDs) are common and often fatal in severe burn patients due to skin barrier loss and immune dysfunction. However, current definitions of invasive mold infections are poorly adapted to this population. This study evaluated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria and their combinations in relation to clinical outcomes in burn patients. We conducted a retrospective cohort study of all patients admitted to the Burn ICU from 2014 to 2023 with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab. Criteria included direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative PCR (qPCR) (Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium) on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among 276 patients, 489/6,184 samples were positive, including 281 skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) and 132 plasma specimens (qPCR). Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 was found in 93 patients (33.7%): Aspergillus (25.7%), Mucorales (10.9%), and Fusarium (9.8%). Twenty-seven patients (9.8%) had ≥2 criteria involving ≥2 mold types. Mortality rose with the number of positive criteria: 12.7% (0), 10.7% (1, 2), 27.3% (3, 4), and 46.7% (≥5) (P < 0.001). Plasma qPCR was positive in 81.3% of Mucorales, 40% of Aspergillus, and 15.4% of Fusarium cases with skin involvement. Skin biopsies (direct examination and conventional culture) combined with species-specific plasma qPCR enhance timely and reliable IFD diagnosis in burn patients. Mortality correlated with the number of positive criteria and coexistence of multiple mold species, underscoring the need for broad antifungal coverage and the value of multi-criteria diagnostics to guide treatment. IMPORTANCE Invasive mold infections are frequent and often fatal complications in patients with severe burns, occurring in up to 20% of cases with a total burn surface area exceeding 15%. Despite their severity, no standardized
summary: This paper investigated the characteristics of various diagnostic criteria for invasive mold infections in patients with severe burn injury. The study included 276 patients with ≥15% total burn surface area and at least one sample sent to the mycology lab, from 2014 to 2023. The diagnostic criteria evaluated were direct microscopy, culture (respiratory, skin, or tissue), species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction for Aspergillus, Mucorales, and Fusarium on plasma/tissue/bronchoalveolar lavage fluid, and serum galactomannan. Among the 489 positive samples, 281 were skin biopsies and 132 were plasma specimens. Positive diagnostic criteria ≥1 were found in 93 patients, with Aspergillus being the most common (25.7%), followed by Mucorales (10.9%) and Fusarium (9.8%). The number of positive criteria correlated with mortality, with 46.7% of patients having ≥5 positive criteria dying. Plasma quantitative polymerase chain reaction was particularly useful for detecting Mucorales infections, being positive in 81.3% of cases with skin involvement. The study highlights the importance of using multiple diagnostic criteria and broad antifungal coverage to treat invasive mold infections in burn patients.  The findings of this study reveal a complex and multifaceted relationship between invasive mold infections, burn injury, and mortality. The use of multiple diagnostic criteria, such as direct microscopy, culture, and species-specific quantitative polymerase chain reaction, enhances the accuracy and reliability of diagnosis. However, the coexistence of multiple mold species and the number of positive criteria also underscore the need for broad antifungal coverage to prevent treatment failure. This study's emphasis on the importance of multi-criteria diagnostics and comprehensive treatment strategies highlights the need for a nuanced understanding of the interplay between human and nonhuman factors in the diagnosis and treatment of invasive mold infections.

title: Dietary curcumin alleviates aflatoxin B1‐induced liver injury and improves growth performance in broilers via Nrf2 activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
source: Wiley: Journal of the Science of Food and Agriculture: Table of Contents
excerpt: Aflatoxin B1 (AFB1), a potent mycotoxin frequently detected in improperly stored poultry feed, induces hepatic oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. Curcumin (CUR), a polyphenolic compound derived from Curcuma longa, exhibits strong antioxidant and anti‐inflammatory activities; however, its efficacy and mechanisms in mitigating AFB1‐induced hepatotoxicity in broilers remain unclear. This study aimed to evaluate the protective effects of dietary CUR supplementation on growth performance and liver health of broilers exposed to AFB1.
summary: This paper investigates the effects of aflatoxin B1 on liver health and growth performance in broilers. AFB1 is a potent mycotoxin commonly found in improperly stored poultry feed, which induces oxidative stress, inflammation, and growth retardation in broilers. The researchers examined whether dietary curcumin supplementation could alleviate AFB1-induced liver injury and improve growth performance in broilers.  The study found that dietary curcumin supplementation mitigated AFB1-induced liver injury and improved growth performance in broilers. This was attributed to the activation of the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 pathway and the inhibition of the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome. The nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 pathway is involved in cellular defense mechanisms against oxidative stress, while the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome plays a role in the regulation of inflammation.  The findings of this study highlight the potential of dietary curcumin supplementation as a strategy to alleviate AFB1-induced liver injury and improve growth performance in broilers. The entanglement of AFB1-induced liver injury and growth retardation in broilers with the activation of the nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 pathway and inhibition of the NOD-like receptor protein 3 inflammasome underscores the complex material relationships between mycotoxins, liver health, and growth performance.

title: Characteristics of individual cyp51A SNPs and combinations thereof impacting the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes of Aspergillus fumigatus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The World Health Organization has flagged the rise of drug resistance in Aspergillus fumigatus as a critical concern. Elevated mutation rates in this pathogen contribute to the rapid development of resistance, complicating treatment efforts. We conducted a study on the prevalence of azole resistance among clinical A. fumigatus isolates in the Netherlands from 1994 to 2022 and identified 34 cyp51A variants. To investigate the impact of individual single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and combinations thereof on the azole phenotype in TR34-mediated resistance genotypes, we focused on novel, recent mutations and explored the effects of SNPs L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S and the combination of the mutations TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S on azole affinity and susceptibility. We created the three-dimensional protein model of the Cyp51A protein with azoles, and the mutation was introduced to the wild-type cyp51A A. fumigatus strain by the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique. Finally, in vitro susceptibility testing of A. fumigatus strains carrying the mutations was conducted to confirm the azole phenotypes observed in clinical isolates. The MICs of all four azoles against the mutated cyp51A strains, which harbored combination mutations, were higher than those of the wild type, with highly elevated MICs of itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. Genotypes TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S mutant showed a consistent phenotype to the clinical strains, which are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. In this study, we show that molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene correlate to the structure–function relationship of in vitro phenotype.
summary: This paper investigates the impact of specific genetic mutations on the resistance of Aspergillus fumigatus to azole medications. The researchers analyzed 34 different variants of the cyp51A gene and identified four single-nucleotide polymorphisms (single nucleotide polymorphisms): L98H, T289A, I364V, and G448S. They also examined the effects of combinations of these mutations, including TR34/L98H, TR34/L98H/T289A/G448S, and TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S. Using a three-dimensional protein model and the CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technique, the researchers introduced these mutations into a wild-type Aspergillus fumigatus strain and tested its susceptibility to four azoles: itraconazole, voriconazole, isavuconazole, and posaconazole. The results showed that the mutated strains had higher minimum inhibitory concentrations for all four azoles, with particularly high minimum inhibitory concentrations for itraconazole, voriconazole, and isavuconazole. The combination mutation TR34/L98H/T289A/I364V/G448S exhibited a observable trait profile consistent with clinical strains that are highly resistant to voriconazole but susceptible to itraconazole. The study's findings suggest a correlation between molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene and the structure-function relationship of the laboratory-based observable trait profile.   The molecular dynamics simulations of amino acid substitutions in the cyp51A gene reveal a complex interplay between genetic variation and drug susceptibility in Aspergillus fumigatus. The emergence of resistant strains highlights the need for continued research into the molecular mechanisms of azole resistance, and the findings of this study underscore the importance of considering the specific genetic context in which drug resistance arises.

title: Antifungal Activity and Resistance Risk of Cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the Causal Agent of Peanut Root Rot
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Peanut root rot (PRR), caused by Fusarium solani, is a common and destructive disease. Cyclobutrifluram exhibits antifungal activity against Fusarium spp., yet its bioactivity and resistance risk against F. solani remain unclear. In this study, the EC50 values of cyclobutrifluram against 155 F. solani strains ranged from 0.0279 to 0.1102 μg/mL, with a mean of 0.0513 ± 0.0170 μg/mL. Treatment with cyclobutrifluram significantly inhibited conidial production and germination, reduced succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) activity, increased hyphal branching, and shortened the distance between septa or cell nuclei. Cyclobutrifluram provided excellent control over PRR. Seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four SDH substitutions (FsSdhBH248Y, FsSdhC1A83V, FsSdhC2A85V, and FsSdhDD184G), which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage PRR.
summary: This paper reports on the antifungal activity and resistance risk of cyclobutrifluram against Fusarium solani, the causal agent of peanut root rot. The study found that cyclobutrifluram exhibited excellent control over the disease, significantly inhibiting conidial production and germination, reducing succinate dehydrogenase activity, and increasing hyphal branching. However, the study also identified seven laboratory-generated cyclobutrifluram-resistant mutants that showed no or slight fitness penalties and exhibited positive cross-resistance only with pydiflumetofen, indicating a moderate-to-high resistance risk. Resistance to cyclobutrifluram in F. solani was conferred by four succinate dehydrogenase substitutions, which was confirmed by molecular docking and gene replacement. This study provides crucial insights for developing effective control strategies to manage peanut root rot.  The findings of this study highlight the complex and dynamic relationship between the pathogen Fusarium solani and the fungicide cyclobutrifluram. While cyclobutrifluram provides excellent control over the disease, the emergence of resistant mutants poses a significant risk. The study's identification of specific succinate dehydrogenase substitutions as the mechanism of resistance underscores the need for a nuanced understanding of the molecular interactions between pathogens and fungicides.

title: Efficacy of Ipflufenoquin against Strawberry Gray Mold: Insights from AlphaFold- Based Structural Modeling and Genome-Wide Transcriptomic Analysis
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea significantly threatens strawberry production. This study evaluated the efficacy of ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase (DHODH) inhibitor, against fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Ipflufenoquin demonstrated a high in vitro sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other pathogens. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of DHODH, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. Additionally, RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.
summary: This paper evaluates the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold caused by Botrytis cinerea in strawberry production. Ipflufenoquin, a novel dihydroorotate dehydrogenase inhibitor, demonstrated high laboratory-based sensitivity to B. cinerea and broad activity against other fungal pathogens isolated from Korean strawberry fields in 2023. Fruit and greenhouse trials confirmed its robust control of gray mold, including strains resistant to multiple fungicide classes. However, treatment shifted the fungal community, promoting less sensitive genera, such as Cladosporium and Rhizopus. Structural modeling with AlphaFold2 and molecular docking confirmed that ipflufenoquin binds to the quinone binding tunnel of dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, correlating binding affinity with susceptibility. RNA-seq analysis revealed that ipflufenoquin suppresses primary metabolic pathways while triggering a robust stress response, up-regulating detoxification and efflux transporter genes. This integrated study confirms the efficacy of ipflufenoquin against gray mold and elucidates its molecular impacts, offering essential data for sustainable management strategies.  The findings of this study highlight the dual nature of ipflufenoquin's impact on fungal communities. While it effectively controls gray mold, it also shifts the community towards less sensitive genera, potentially creating new management challenges. This tension between efficacy and unintended consequences underscores the complexities of using chemical controls in agricultural ecosystems.

title: Identification and characterization of a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound targeting the Aspergillus fumigatus cell wall and cell membrane and inducing oxidative stress
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT The substantial increase in fungal diseases, the limited availability of antifungal drugs, and rising resistance to existing treatments highlight the urgent need for developing novel antifungal drugs. Natural products, known for their diverse bioactivities and unique structures, remain critical sources for antifungal drug discovery. In this study, we aimed to identify novel antifungal compounds from soil microbes and isolated a novel 28-membered polyene macrolide, compound 1 , from Kitasatospora melanogena . This compound demonstrated potent antifungal activity, with MICs of 4–16 μg/mL against Aspergillus fumigatus , Aspergillus flavus , Candida albicans , and Cryptococcus neoformans . Treatment with compound 1 led to significant growth reduction and disruption of the cell wall and membrane in A. fumigatus compared to the wild-type. To understand the underlying mechanism, we performed a transcriptomic analysis of A. fumigatus exposed to compound 1 , revealing a substantial downregulation of genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Additionally, compound 1 induced oxidative stress, leading to elevated reactive oxygen species levels. These multifaceted mechanisms highlight the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents. Natural products remain a proven source of antifungal agents, but few new scaffolds have been introduced in recent decades. We identified a novel polyene macrolide from Kitasatospora melanogena with potent activity against major fungal pathogens. This compound disrupts both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, revealing a multifaceted mechanism of action. summary: This paper identifies a novel broad-spectrum antifungal compound, compound 1, isolated from the soil microbe Kitasatospora melanogena. Compound 1 demonstrates potent antifungal activity against Aspergillus fumigatus, Aspergillus flavus, Candida albicans, and Cryptococcus neoformans, with minimum inhibitory concentrations ranging from 4 to 16 micrograms per milliliter. Microscopic examination reveals that compound 1 disrupts the cell wall and membrane of A. fumigatus, leading to significant growth reduction. gene-expression analysis analysis shows that compound 1 downregulates genes involved in cell wall and membrane biogenesis, as well as those encoding integral membrane proteins and multidrug transporters. Furthermore, compound 1 induces oxidative stress, resulting in elevated levels of reactive oxygen species. This multifaceted mechanism of action highlights the potential of K. melanogena natural products in the development of novel antifungal agents.  The identification of compound 1 as a broad-spectrum antifungal agent underscores the importance of soil microbes as a reservoir for novel antifungal compounds. The duality of compound 1's action, disrupting both the fungal cell wall and membrane while inducing oxidative stress, underscores the complex interplay between fungal biology and environmental pressures. The potential of natural products like compound 1 to combat rising resistance to existing treatments and the limited availability of antifungal drugs highlights the urgent need for further research into the antifungal properties of soil microbes.

title: Nano-Stimulated Immunity: Synthesis and Functionalization of CuS Induce Multilevel Defense Responses against Fusarium in Tomato (Solanum lycopersicum)
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: This study investigated how doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles (MNPs) influence tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three cuboidal CuS MNPs─undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS)─were foliarly applied to Fusarium-infected plants in a greenhouse study. Fe-CuS led to the highest Cu accumulation in leaves─15.7 and 158.4% higher than undoped CuS and Ce-CuS, respectively, likely due to its positive charge facilitating stronger electrostatic interactions and more efficient NPs uptake. Compared to the untreated control, the Fe-CuS foliar application resulted in a 487.7% increase in shoot biomass and a 36.8% reduction in wilt damage through activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, indicating a dual role of CuS MNPs as both a micronutrient carrier and an immune stimulant. Importantly, copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) activation may link Cu homeostasis to stress-induced H2O2 production, indicating a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity. These findings underscore the significant potential for CuS MNPs as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides, though long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts warrant further evaluation.
summary: This paper investigated the impact of doping-modified copper sulfide (CuS) micronanoparticles on tomato resistance against fungal pathogens. Three types of CuS micronanoparticles - undoped (CuS), iron-doped (Fe-CuS), and cerium-doped (Ce-CuS) - were applied to Fusarium-infected tomato plants in a greenhouse study. The iron-doped CuS (Fe-CuS) particles accumulated the most copper in the leaves, resulting in a significant increase in shoot biomass and a reduction in wilt damage. These effects were attributed to the activation of jasmonic acid/ethylene signaling, which suggests that CuS micronanoparticles can act as both micronutrient carriers and immune stimulants.  The findings of this study highlight the potential of CuS micronanoparticles as an alternative to conventional copper-based fungicides. However, further evaluation of the long-term environmental behavior and life cycle impacts of these particles is necessary. The activation of copper amine oxidases (CuAOs) and the resulting stress-induced H2O2 production may also provide a novel mechanism for nanoparticle-enabled plant immunity.  The entanglement of CuS micronanoparticles with plant immunity reveals a complex interplay between metal homeostasis and stress responses. While CuS micronanoparticles can induce a robust defense response in tomato plants, their long-term environmental implications remain uncertain. This study underscores the need for a nuanced understanding of the relationships between nanoparticles, plant immunity, and ecosystem dynamics.

title: A combined genetic and chemical approach for identifying novel antifungal compounds against Fusarium graminearum
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Chemical fungicides act by targeting specific proteins or pathways, known as modes of action (MoAs). In this study, we established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. Target genes corresponding to major fungicide classes were deleted by homologous recombination, and the resulting mutants exhibited altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides compared with the wild-type strain. Deletion of genes encoding known fungicide targets revealed distinct sensitivity profiles, supporting MoA prediction. Using the platform that detects sensitivity differences through OD₆₀₀ changes, we examined a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules and identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway. Several of these compounds exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity, underscoring their potential as novel scaffolds for future development. Collectively, this platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, with broad applicability to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. IMPORTANCE This study provides a perspective on developing strategies to manage fungal pathogens with implications for agriculture and food security. The effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance, narrow target ranges, and environmental concerns. By combining genetic approaches with chemical screening, this work offers a more systematic way to identify candidate antifungal agents and better understand their possible mechanisms. The framework may also be adapted for use in other areas, including medical and veterinary applications, suggesting potential broader applicability. In addition, the emphasis on exploring new molecular scaffolds supports efforts to develop more sustainable and long-term disease management strategies. Overall, this st
summary: This paper established a systematic screening platform using Fusarium graminearum gene knockout mutants to evaluate the efficacy of fungicides and identify novel antifungal compounds. The platform involved deleting genes encoding known fungicide targets, resulting in altered sensitivity to the corresponding fungicides in the mutants compared with the wild-type strain. By examining a chemical library of 2,704 small molecules, the researchers identified 8 compounds with activity likely involved in the osmotic signal transduction pathway, several of which exhibited previously unreported antifungal activity. These compounds have potential as novel scaffolds for future development. The platform provides a robust, mechanism-informed system for antifungal discovery, applicable to synthetic agents, natural products, and biocontrol metabolites. This study may contribute to developing strategies to manage fungal pathogens, particularly in agriculture and food security, where the effectiveness of current fungicides is increasingly limited by resistance and other concerns.

title: Homologous Overexpression of Phosphatidate Phosphatase (Lipin) in the Oleaginous Fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11 Enhances Lipid Accumulation under Static Solid Cultivation and Submerged Fermentation
source: acs: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry: Table of Contents
excerpt: Lipin, a phosphatidic acid phosphatase, catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol (TAG) biosynthesis, and acts as a transcriptional coregulator of lipid metabolism. In this study, the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) was overexpressed in Mucor circinelloides WJ11 to evaluate its impact on lipid accumulation under submerged (SmF) and solid-state fermentation (SSF). Under SSF, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia compared to the control strain. Total fatty acid (TFA) content increased by 35.7% in mycelia, while in spores it increased from 10% to 18% of dry cell weight, indicating a substantial enhancement in lipid yield. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3 and a reduced C18:1 content. RT-qPCR indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 h under SSF, coinciding with upregulation of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These results suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing TAG biosynthesis under SSF for potential industrial lipid production.
summary: This paper reports on the overexpression of the Lipin-encoding gene (McLipin) in the oleaginous fungus Mucor circinelloides WJ11. Lipin is a phosphatidic acid phosphatase that catalyzes the conversion of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol, a key step in triacylglycerol biosynthesis.  McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight and total fatty acid content under static solid cultivation and submerged fermentation. Specifically, under solid-state fermentation, McLipin overexpression increased cell dry weight by 19% in spores and 36.9% in mycelia, and total fatty acid content increased by 35.7% in mycelia. Fatty acid profiling showed elevated proportions of C16:0, C18:2, and C18:3, while C18:1 content was reduced. RT-quantitative polymerase chain reaction results indicated that McLipin expression peaked at 24 hours under solid-state fermentation, coinciding with the increased activity of ACC, FAS, cME, and NADPH-generating genes. These findings suggest that McLipin overexpression reprograms lipid metabolism, significantly enhancing triacylglycerol biosynthesis under solid-state fermentation for potential industrial lipid production.  The results of this study highlight the potential of Mucor circinelloides WJ11 as a biotechnological platform for lipid production. The observed increase in lipid accumulation and altered fatty acid profiles suggest that McLipin overexpression can be leveraged to enhance industrial lipid production. However, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms underlying this phenomenon and to optimize the conditions for large-scale production.

title: Beyond Fumigatus: a molecular portrait of clinical Aspergillus diversity, pathogenicity, and antifungal resistance
source: American Society for Microbiology: Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Aspergillus infection poses a major clinical challenge, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, with invasive diseases associated with high mortality. While Aspergillus fumigatus remains the predominant species causing human infections, recent studies highlight the growing clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, which often exhibit reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies. In this study, we analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. A total of 38 Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections were identified, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species accounting for 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto (22.9%), A. sydowii (8.7%), A. calidoustus (7.1%), A. nidulans (6.6%), A. tanneri (6.1%), and A. terreus (5.6%). Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS). In contrast, PCR sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis (35%), chronic granulomatous disease (22%), and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection (17%). Out of 107 patients, eight died (8/107, 7.5%); six of these deaths occurred in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) and two in patients with RAG1 deficiency. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species. In contrast, the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii. summary: This paper analyzed 196 clinical Aspergillus isolates from 107 patients treated at the NIH Clinical Center between 2019 and 2022. The isolates belonged to 38 different Aspergillus species across 11 taxonomic sections, with non-fumigatus and cryptic species making up 77.1% of all isolates. The most frequently recovered species were A. fumigatus sensu stricto, A. sydowii, A. calidoustus, A. nidulans, A. tanneri, and A. terreus. Species-level identification was achieved in 43% of isolates using matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry, while polymerase chain reaction sequencing confirmed species identity in over 88% of isolates by targeting the internal transcribed spacer region of rDNA, 81% using the β-tubulin gene, and 68% using the calmodulin gene. The most common underlying clinical conditions among patients were bronchiectasis, chronic granulomatous disease, and pulmonary non-tuberculous mycobacterial infection. Eight patients died, with six of these deaths occurring in patients with chronic granulomatous disease. Antifungal susceptibility testing showed that olorofim had the lowest minimal inhibitory concentrations across species, while the activity of triazoles and amphotericin B was variable, particularly against A. tanneri, A. calidoustus, and A. sydowii.  The clinical significance of lesser-known and cryptic Aspergillus species, often exhibiting reduced susceptibility to standard antifungal therapies, underscores the complexity of Aspergillus infections. The entanglement of Aspergillus species with human health, particularly in immune-weakened individuals, highlights the need for accurate species-level identification and targeted antifungal treatment strategies.

title: Production of ETP-Type (Epipolythiodioxopiperazine) Mycotoxins in Clinical Fungal Isolates
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine (ETP) toxin, has been reported in several fungal species, but its distribution remains unclear. We analyzed 140 clinical isolates from two major hospitals using HPLC and LC-MS/MS to assess gliotoxin production. Gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct ETP-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific ETP profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.
summary: This paper analyzed 140 clinical fungal isolates from two major hospitals to assess the production of gliotoxin, an epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxin. The isolates were from various fungal species, but gliotoxin was detected only in Aspergillus fumigatus isolates, with no production observed in any other species under multiple culture conditions. Molecular networking and comparative genomics revealed distinct epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in non-A. fumigatus species, including aspirochlorine derivatives in Aspergillus flavus and aranotin-related metabolites in Aspergillus terreus. These findings clarify species-specific epipolythiodioxopiperazine profiles and confirm A. fumigatus as the sole gliotoxin producer among the isolates examined.  The capacity of Aspergillus fumigatus to produce gliotoxin, a compound capable of causing harm to humans, is well-documented. However, the presence of distinct epipolythiodioxopiperazine-related pathways in other fungal species, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus terreus, suggests that these organisms may also play a role in the production and distribution of epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxins. The entanglement of these fungal species in the production of epipolythiodioxopiperazine toxins raises questions about the ecological and social dynamics that shape the emergence and spread of mycotoxins in clinical and environmental contexts.

title: Antibacterial and Cytotoxic Decahydrofluorene-Class Alkaloids from the Marine-Derived Fungus Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512
source: acs: Journal of Natural Products: Table of Contents
excerpt: Eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), together with 13 known analogues (9-21) were isolated from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. Their structures were determined by extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established by quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra, by a comparison of experimental ECD spectra, or by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. Compound 1 rarely contains an oxime hydroxy with a 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system. A plausible biosynthetic pathway for 1 and 2 was proposed. Biologically, compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 had cytotoxicity against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116 with IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, and 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 also showed significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria with MIC values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. Their structure-bioactivity relationship was also discussed.
summary: This paper describes the isolation and characterization of eight new decahydrofluorene-class alkaloids, pyrrospirones R-Y (1-8), and 13 known analogues (9-21) from the marine-derived fungal strain Penicillium sp. SCSIO 41512. The structures of these compounds were determined through extensive spectroscopic analysis, and their absolute configurations were established using quantum chemical calculations of electronic circular dichroism spectra, experimental electronic circular dichroism spectra, or single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis. The compounds showed a range of bioactivities, including toxicity to cells against human cancer cell lines A549 and HCT116, and significant inhibitory activity against six pathogenic bacteria. The toxicity to cells of compounds 1, 4, 6, 8, 10-12, 14-15, 18-19, and 21 was measured at IC50 values of 7.3-79.3 μM, while the antibacterial activity of compounds 1, 4, 6, 11, 15, 18, and 21 was measured at minimum inhibitory concentration values of 1.6-13.0 μg/mL. The structure-bioactivity relationship of these compounds was also discussed.  The findings of this study highlight the potential of marine-derived fungi as a source of novel bioactive compounds. The discovery of these compounds with significant antibacterial and cell-damaging activities suggests that they may be useful in the development of new treatments for human diseases. However, further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms of action of these compounds and to explore their potential as therapeutic agents. The complex polycyclic systems found in these compounds, such as the 6/5/6/5/6/13 polycyclic system in compound 1, also highlight the intricate and diverse structures that can be produced by fungal metabolism, underscoring the importance of continued exploration of the fungal kingdom for novel bioactive compounds.

title: Advancing mold identification in the routine laboratory, performance of smartphone-based imaging and a newly developed convolutional neural network
source: American Society for Microbiology: Microbiology Spectrum: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Mold identification in clinical diagnostics is traditionally labor-intensive and is dependent on expert interpretation. MoldVision is a deep-learning approach that uses smartphone images of mold cultures to automate identification. We analyzed 161 clinical isolates across four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (with A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. Daily images were captured from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days using a standardized smartphone setup, generating over 4,000 images. We trained three variations of Visual Geometry Group 16 (VGG16) convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and benchmarked the best-performing model (VGG16 with dual classification heads) against LightGBM models trained on pre-extracted features and human expert assessments at various time points. The best-performing VGG16 model achieved a mean (SD) AUROC of 92.7% ± 1.8% and sensitivity of 68.7% ± 2.6% across all species. Here, the performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. was best (AUROC of 99.9% ± 0.1%, fivefold cross-validation mean and SD). Regarding the evaluations over time, early-stage classification (days 1–2) was challenging (F1-score 38.8% ± 3.5% across all species) but improved significantly on days 3–5 (F1 92.1% ± 2.8% across all species). Compared to experts, MoldVision consistently showed superior performance, particularly in mature cultures, detecting subtle morphological features earlier and more accurately. Our results demonstrate that CNNs integrated with low-cost smartphone imaging can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, outperforming human experts in many cases. This approach offers a practical and scalable solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise, especially in resource-limited settings. IMPORTANCE Timely, accurate mold identification can save lives, yet today it often requires days of growth and scarce expert time. MoldVision offers a practical alterna
summary: This paper analyzed 161 clinical isolates of four common mold genera: Penicillium spp., Aspergillus spp. (including A. flavus and A. fumigatus), Fusarium spp., and Cladosporium spp. using a smartphone-based imaging system and a convolutional neural network approach called MoldVision. The researchers captured over 4,000 images of mold cultures from the top and bottom of culture plates over 5 days and trained three variations of the VGG16 convolutional neural network. The best-performing model achieved a mean area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 92.7% and sensitivity of 68.7% across all species, with the highest performance in identifying Cladosporium spp. (area under the receiver operating characteristic curve of 99.9%). The convolutional neural network approach outperformed human expert assessments, particularly in mature cultures, and demonstrated improved performance over time, with early-stage classification becoming more accurate on days 3-5. This study suggests that smartphone-based imaging and convolutional neural networks can reliably classify mold species in routine diagnostics, offering a practical solution for laboratories lacking specialized mycology expertise.  The tension between expert time and timely, accurate mold identification is highlighted by the researchers' findings. The use of low-cost smartphone imaging and convolutional neural networks not only outperforms human experts in many cases but also offers a scalable solution for resource-limited settings, where expert time is scarce. This approach underscores the material entanglement between technology, expertise, and access to healthcare resources.

title: GSNOR is essential for nitric oxide homeostasis and involved in aflatoxin biosynthesis and pathogenicity in Aspergillus flavus
source: American Society for Microbiology: Applied and Environmental Microbiology: Table of Contents
excerpt: ABSTRACT Nitric oxide (NO) is an important biological signaling molecule. S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR), a master regulator of NO signaling, regulates various biological processes. However, little is known about the role of GSNOR in Aspergillus flavus. Here, we identified a gene encoding GSNOR in this aflatoxigenic fungus and demonstrated that GSNOR shows activity during the critical life cycle stages, including spore germination, hyphal growth, and conidiogenesis. We found that GSNOR plays a crucial role in NO homeostasis, as GSNOR deletion resulted in significantly elevated NO levels and heightened sensitivity to exogenous NO stress. GSNOR also participated in multiple biological processes in A. flavus; for that, GSNOR deletion impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, decreased conidiogenesis and sclerotial development, attenuated virulence on kernels, and notably decreased aflatoxin production. Furthermore, we demonstrated that GSNOR is important for reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance, as its deletion significantly elevated mycelial ROS levels and made the strain more sensitive to oxidative stress. IMPORTANCE Aspergillus flavus is a notorious saprophytic filamentous fungus, with its production of carcinogenic aflatoxins posing serious threats to food safety and human health. Aflatoxin contamination prevention and control have long been a global challenge. In previous studies, we observed that nitric oxide (NO) significantly inhibits the aflatoxin production by A. flavus. This study further investigated the role of the key regulatory enzyme S-nitrosoglutathione reductase (GSNOR) in the NO signaling pathway. Our findings indicate that GSNOR is crucial for maintaining both NO homeostasis and reactive oxygen species (ROS) balance and plays an essential role in fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis. summary: This paper investigates the role of S-nitrosoglutathione reductase in the nitric oxide signaling pathway of Aspergillus flavus, a fungus that produces carcinogenic aflatoxins. The researchers identified a gene encoding S-nitrosoglutathione reductase in this fungus and demonstrated its activity during critical life stages, including spore germination and hyphal growth. They found that S-nitrosoglutathione reductase deletion resulted in elevated nitric oxide levels, impaired conidia germination, reduced growth, and decreased aflatoxin production. The study also revealed that S-nitrosoglutathione reductase is involved in reactive oxygen species balance and fungal pathogenicity. The findings suggest that targeting components in the nitric oxide signaling pathway, such as S-nitrosoglutathione reductase, could be a novel strategy for preventing aflatoxin contamination. The research highlights the complex interactions between NO, reactive oxygen species, and fungal development, pathogenicity, and aflatoxin biosynthesis in Aspergillus flavus.  The tension between S-nitrosoglutathione reductase's role in maintaining nitric oxide homeostasis and its involvement in aflatoxin biosynthesis reflects the duality of this enzyme in fungal metabolism. As a regulator of nitric oxide signaling, S-nitrosoglutathione reductase is essential for fungal development and pathogenicity, but its activity also contributes to the production of carcinogenic aflatoxins. This paradox underscores the material entanglement between fungal metabolism and human health, where the same biological processes that facilitate fungal growth and disease-causing ability also pose threats to food safety and human well-being.
